Detailed Description

This class implements the learning part of the NoisyOR discrimination model.

Given a binary class variable , and a set of discrete attribute variables , the idea of the NoisyOR model is to assume that the value of the binary class variable is the deterministic result of the OR operator on another set of intermediate (latent) binary variables . The parameters of the distributions are computed using an EM algorithm (see the corresponding initial and transformed graphs at the end of this section).

This leads to the formula:

The learning algorithm computes the parameter matrix for using an iterative algorithm (EM). Thus, unlike the other learning objects, plLearnNoisyOR is not incremental and needs to store all the data points added using plLearnObject::add_point().

             C

          ^    ^
         /      \
        /        \
       /          \
      /            \
     /              \

    A1                An

      INITIAL MODEL



            |
            |
            |
            |
            |
            V 



            C

          ^    ^
         /      \
        /        \
       /          \
      /            \
     /              \

    B1  .........    Bn

    ^                 ^
    |                 |
    |   .........     |
    |                 |
    |                 |
    |                 |

    A1                An

      TRANSFORMED MODEL

Member Function Documentation

plCndDistribution plLearnNoisyOR::get_cnd_distribution ( ) const
virtual

Constructs the conditional distribution corresponding to the learnt conditional distribution.

It computes the parameter matrix for using an EM algorithm and returns a plNoisyOR with the computed parameters.

Implements plLearnCndObject.

unsigned int plLearnNoisyOR::get_n_parameters ( ) const
virtual

Returns the ACTUAL number of parameters.

It could be different from the number of parameters returned by get_parameters.

For example, the actual number of parameters of a N dimensional normal distribution is N + N*(N+1)/2 because the covariance matrix is symmetric.

Implements plLearnObject.
